definition: neck/collar/to lead/to receive/classifier for clothes, mats, screens etc

sentences.english: Can you find a guide to pilot the boat into the little harbour?
sentences.chinese: 你能找位领航员将船引进这个小港湾吗？

sentences.english: Lots of pilots plot to dot the rotten rogrinding bot.
sentences.chinese: 多量领航员规划给腐烂的机器人打点。

sentences.english: Lift up the pilots bag from the pilot boat.
sentences.chinese: 把领航员的包从领航艇上吊上来。

sentences.english: Lift up the pilots bag from the pilot boat.
sentences.chinese: 把领航员的包从领航艇上吊上来。

sentences.english: Yards of thick 48mm tensile chrome-moly steel completely surround driver and co-driver.
sentences.chinese: 码厚四十八毫米拉伸铬钼钢完全环绕司机和领航员。

sentences.english: One of the top 500 companies in USA.
sentences.chinese: 美国500强企业，保护包装行业领航者。

sentences.english: Pilotage service in Hong Kong is provided through a private company, namely the Hong Kong Pilotage Association.
sentences.chinese: 香港的领航服务由一家私营公司香港领港会提供。

sentences.english: True Nobility In a calm sea every man is a pilot.
sentences.chinese: 风平浪静的大海，每个人都是领航员。

sentences.english: In 28, for the most competent pilot who is always particularly the surging waves.
sentences.chinese: 对于最有能力的领航人风浪总是格外的汹涌。

sentences.english: In the future, we will surpass the past.
sentences.chinese: 我们将超越历史，成为外贸领航者之一。

sentences.english: PKF is a classical hotel consultant brand that leads international financial technology.
sentences.chinese: 领航于国际专业财务技术的经典酒店顾问品牌。

sentences.english: You are like a captain navigating a ship.
sentences.chinese: 你就像一位船长，为一艘船领航。

sentences.english: Shida - The Leader of Superior Quality Rechargeable Battery.
sentences.chinese: 实达，高品质环保充电电池的领航者。

sentences.english: Cebu Port may notify the pilot station pilot, there is no port communication station.
sentences.chinese: 可通知宿务港领航站引航，没有港口通讯电台。

sentences.english: Mark used to a pilot on the Mississippi River.
sentences.chinese: 马克曾遮密西硒比河上挡过领航毡。

sentences.english: In a calm sea every man is a pilot.
sentences.chinese: 风平浪静的大海，每个人都是领航员。

definition: (of a ship) to set sail/(of an aeroplane) to take off/also written 起航[qi3 hang2]
(of a ship) to set sail/(of an aeroplane) to take off/also written 啟航|启航[qi3 hang2]
to set sail on a voyage to a distant place/(fig.) to undertake a great mission
to crane one's neck/to await eagerly/to lead/to show the way
course/direction (a ship or plane is heading in)
to travel a great distance by sea or air/voyage/long-haul flight
